cards.title: I've got two boyfriends. It's time polyamory became socially acceptable
cards.rawTitle: I've got two boyfriends. It's time polyamory became socially acceptable

item.title: I've got two boyfriends. It's time polyamory became socially acceptable
item.trailText: Simon Copland and his two partners believe love is limitless. Why should they miss out on social and legal benefits that other couples enjoy?
item.standFirst:
Simon Copland's two partners know about each other. In fact, it was James who introduced him to Martyn. Their polyamorous lifestyle is based on the belief that love is limitless. But if all love is equal, why do those in alternative relationships miss out on social and legal benefits that other couples enjoy?

â€¢ Why I'm polyamorous and proud
item.byline: Simon Copland, Leah Green, Maya Wolfe-Robinson, Tom Silverstone and Bruno Rinvolucri

cards.title: Virtual reality headsets from Oculus, Microsoft and Sony game it out
cards.rawTitle: Virtual reality headsets from Oculus, Microsoft and Sony game it out

item.title: E3 2015: Virtual reality headsets from Oculus, Microsoft and Sony game it out
item.trailText: Virtual reality is front and centre at the opening of the Electronic Entertainment Expo 2015 - better known as E3 - in Los Angeles, with Oculus, Sony and Microsoft all lined up to make it a technology battleground
item.standFirst: Virtual reality is front and centre at the opening of the Electronic Entertainment Expo 2015 - better known as E3 - in Los Angeles, with Oculus, Sony and Microsoft all lined up to make it a technology battleground. Dan Ackerman, a senior editor at CNET, the online technology and consumer electronics review site, believes user-friendly VR might finally be here

stillImage.caption: A man at the E3 convention wears Sony Playstation's virtual reality headset. 17 June 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: Summer season / South of England show

item.title: South of England show: a visual tour
item.trailText: Guardian photojournalist Graeme Robertson went to Ardingly to take a look at the South of England show for the fourth piece in our summer season series
item.standFirst:
Guardian photojournalist Graeme Robertson went to Ardingly to take a look at the South of England agricultural show for the fourth piece in our summer season series, looking at key events around the UK

  • Sarah Leeâ€™s Chelsea flower show
  • Graeme Robertsonâ€™s Glyndebourne opera festival
  • Christopher Thomondâ€™s Appleby horse fair

displayImages.altText: South of England Show
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Graeme Robertson for the Guardian

item.title: Wedge sandals: the wish list
item.trailText: The wedge sandal is the perfect footwear solution for summer, comfortable, directional and ticks both the bohemian and seventies trends.
item.standFirst: The wedge sandal is the perfect footwear solution for summer. Itâ€™s comfortable, directional and ticks both the bohemian and 70s trends. Choose from wood, raffia or a chunky white tractor sole topped in leopard print, tan or metallic leather. These sandals are a perfect finish to your new seasonâ€™s looks.

cards.title: Noel Fielding draws his self-portrait / I'm a pointy old witch

item.title: Noel Fielding's self-portrait: 'I'm a pointy old witch'
item.trailText: Comedian Noel Fielding analyses his reflection while looking down the lens of the camera and drawing his self-portrait on an iPad
item.standFirst:
Comedian Noel Fielding analyses his reflection while looking down the lens of the camera and drawing his self-portrait on an iPad. His unique artistic style â€“ which fans of The Mighty Boosh will recognise â€“ reveals the complexities of his many personas, including the ones he wants to 'stab to death'

More self-portraits: Gillian Anderson | Ashley Walters | Tara Fitzgerald | Gok Wan
item.byline: Juliet Riddell, Jess Gormley, Tom Silverstone, Noah Payne-Frank and Pascal Wyse

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Noel Fielding's self portrait: 'I'm a pointy old witch'  video Photograph: guardian.co.uk

sublinks.title: Gillian Anderson / 'As I step into a room it shifts things'
sublinks.rawTitle: 'As I step into a room it shifts things'

item.title: Gillian Anderson's self-portrait: 'I know that as soon as I step into a room it shifts things and I wish it wouldn't'
item.trailText: Actor Gillian Anderson analyses her reflection while looking down the lens of the camera and drawing her self-portrait on an iPad
item.standFirst:
Actor Gillian Anderson analyses her reflection while looking down the lens of the camera and drawing her self-portrait on an iPad. Through this intimate process she reveals her thoughts about her perception of her own beauty, her insecurities and how fame has affected her

More self-portraits: Ashley Walters | Tara Fitzgerald | Gok Wan | Noel Fielding
item.byline: Juliet Riddell, Jess Gormley, Tom Silverstone, Noah Payne-Frank and Pascal Wyse

cards.title: Flash forward / The rising stars of British photography
cards.rawTitle: The rising stars of British photography

item.title: Flash forward: the rising stars of British photography
item.trailText: From hunting meteorites to capturing Indiaâ€™s LGBT community, here is a selection of their best shots
item.standFirst: From hunting meteorites to capturing Indiaâ€™s LGBT community, FreshFaced + WildEyed at the Photographerâ€™s Gallery brings together the work of 25 emerging photographers and artists from around the UK â€“ here are some of their best shots

displayImages.caption:
Untitled, from the series Looking for Alice by Sian Davey
Daveyâ€™s photographs feature her three-year-old daughter Alice, who was born with Downâ€™s Syndrome. The project reflects the familyâ€™s personal story while also examining attitudes in society towards young people with Downâ€™s.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 1
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Untitled, from the series Looking for Alice by Sian Davey
Daveyâ€™s photographs feature her three-year-old daughter Alice, who was born with Downâ€™s Syndrome. The project reflects the familyâ€™s personal story while also examining attitudes in society towards young people with Downâ€™s.

displayImages.caption:
Girls! Girls! Girls! (2011-2015) by Francesca Jane Allen
This playful photographic series explores the transition between adolescence and womanhood, combining diary-like images with staged portraits touching on themes of friendship, love, sexuality and identity.
displayImages.credit: Francesca Jane Allen/Courtesy of the artist
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 2
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Girls! Girls! Girls! (2011-2015) by Francesca Jane Allen
This playful photographic series explores the transition between adolescence and womanhood, combining diary-like images with staged portraits touching on themes of friendship, love, sexuality and identity.

displayImages.caption:
Porters (2014), by Jill Quigley
Using splashes of paint, spray and bright props, Quigley stages colourful and playful interventions in abandoned Irish cottages, filling empty interiors with signs of movement and life.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 3
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Porters (2014), by Jill Quigley
Using splashes of paint, spray and bright props, Quigley stages colourful and playful interventions in abandoned Irish cottages, filling empty interiors with signs of movement and life.

displayImages.caption:
Red Nails (2014), by Rebecca Scheinberg
Rebecca Scheinberg uses the polished look of advertising and magazine photography to entice us with her images of perfect bodies. But the photos also suggest a darker story at work beneath the glossy sheen.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 4
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Red Nails (2014), by Rebecca Scheinberg
Rebecca Scheinberg uses the polished look of advertising and magazine photography to entice us with her images of perfect bodies. But the photos also suggest a darker story at work beneath the glossy sheen.

displayImages.caption:
I Am Fine (2014), by Jonathan Simpson
This video project investigates the dangerous and exploitative conditions of Singaporeâ€™s migrant workers, mainly Bangladeshi men who leave their families for several years at a time in order to support them. Simpson delivered video messages of love and support between the workers and their families, documenting the emotional impact of their separation.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 5
displayImages.cleanCaption:
I Am Fine (2014), by Jonathan Simpson
This video project investigates the dangerous and exploitative conditions of Singaporeâ€™s migrant workers, mainly Bangladeshi men who leave their families for several years at a time in order to support them. Simpson delivered video messages of love and support between the workers and their families, documenting the emotional impact of their separation.

displayImages.caption:
Blue Mountain, from the series The Meteorite Hunter (2014), by Alexandra Lethbridge
Lethbridge hunts for meteorites, exploring the places they come from and where they land, and documenting the artifacts she has accumulated in her search.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 6
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Blue Mountain, from the series The Meteorite Hunter (2014), by Alexandra Lethbridge
Lethbridge hunts for meteorites, exploring the places they come from and where they land, and documenting the artifacts she has accumulated in her search.

displayImages.caption:
San Diego, from American Series (2013-ongoing), by Emma Gruner
Referencing the aesthetics of mainstream pornography, Grunerâ€™s images explore our modern fascination with self-representation and visual pleasure.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced + WildEyed 2015 7
displayImages.cleanCaption:
San Diego, from American Series (2013-ongoing), by Emma Gruner
Referencing the aesthetics of mainstream pornography, Grunerâ€™s images explore our modern fascination with self-representation and visual pleasure.

displayImages.caption:
A Handful of Soil for the Whole Horizon #7 (2014), by Liz Orton
Combining scientific, poetic, performative and documentary elements â€“ including material from survival manuals â€“ Liz Orton depicts the human world destructively entangled with nature.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 8
displayImages.cleanCaption:
A Handful of Soil for the Whole Horizon #7 (2014), by Liz Orton
Combining scientific, poetic, performative and documentary elements â€“ including material from survival manuals â€“ Liz Orton depicts the human world destructively entangled with nature.

displayImages.caption:
Untitled #6, from Kothis, Hijras, Giriyas and Others (2013-14), by Charan Singh
Singhâ€™s work is informed by 13 years of HIV/AIDS work and community activism in India. The Kothis (effeminate, underprivileged, homosexual men), Hijras (eunuchs), Giriyas (partners of Kothi and Hijra) are indigenous terms used by communities to define different sexual identities.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 9
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Untitled #6, from Kothis, Hijras, Giriyas and Others (2013-14), by Charan Singh
Singhâ€™s work is informed by 13 years of HIV/AIDS work and community activism in India. The Kothis (effeminate, underprivileged, homosexual men), Hijras (eunuchs), Giriyas (partners of Kothi and Hijra) are indigenous terms used by communities to define different sexual identities.

displayImages.caption:
Roots (2014), by Mandukhai Kaylin
Through a combination of still and moving images, Mandukhai Kaylinâ€™s work examines the blurred boundaries between the real and the artificial. Photograph: Mandukhai Kaylin/Courtesy of the artist
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 10
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Roots (2014), by Mandukhai Kaylin
Through a combination of still and moving images, Mandukhai Kaylinâ€™s work examines the blurred boundaries between the real and the artificial.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mandukhai Kaylin/Courtesy of the artist

displayImages.caption:
X-Ray: Inside Venezuelan Public Hospitals (2014), by Betty Laura Zapata
Venezuela is experiencing one of the biggest economic and political crises in its history, and this undercover photographic project documents the state of public healthcare in the country. Only 16,000 hospital beds are used out of the 42,000 beds available, and patients that get a bed have little privacy.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 11
displayImages.cleanCaption:
X-Ray: Inside Venezuelan Public Hospitals (2014), by Betty Laura Zapata
Venezuela is experiencing one of the biggest economic and political crises in its history, and this undercover photographic project documents the state of public healthcare in the country. Only 16,000 hospital beds are used out of the 42,000 beds available, and patients that get a bed have little privacy.

displayImages.caption:
Beach Boys (2014) by James Bell
Beach Boys documents the bar owners, street vendors and hustlers of Dover Beach, Barbados, a popular and lucrative tourist location. The images capture the vulnerability of a community dependent on the tourist trade.
displayImages.altText: FreshFaced+WildEyed 2015 12
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Beach Boys (2014) by James Bell
Beach Boys documents the bar owners, street vendors and hustlers of Dover Beach, Barbados, a popular and lucrative tourist location. The images capture the vulnerability of a community dependent on the tourist trade.
